natural problem: If the three lines $3y-2x=1$, $x+2y=2$ and $4x-6y=5$ are drawn in the plane, how many points will lie at the intersection of at least two of the three lines?
natural solution: In general, two lines intersect in exactly one point, unless they are parallel, in which case they are either the same line or have no intersection points. First, check to see if any of these lines are parallel.
The first line $3y-2x=1$ has a slope of $2/3$,  the second line has a slope of $-1/2$, and the third line has a slope of $4/6=2/3$.
So, the first and third lines are parallel.
We can easily check that these are not the same line.
Therefore, these two lines do not intersect anywhere, and the third line intersects each of them in exactly one point, for a total of $\boxed{2}$ intersection points.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes line1 line2 line3 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. line1 x y = (3 * y - 2 * x = 1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. line2 x y = (x + 2 * y = 2)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x y. line3 x y = (4 * x - 6 * y = 5)"
shows  "card {p. \<exists> x y. p = (x, y) \<and> ((line1 x y \<and> line2 x y) \<or> (line1 x y \<and> line3 x y) \<or> (line2 x y \<and> line3 x y))} = 2"

 In general, two lines intersect in exactly one point, unless they are parallel, in which case they are either the same line or have no intersection points. First, check to see if any of these lines are parallel.
 The first line $3y-2x=1$ has a slope of $2/3$,  the second line has a slope of $-1/2$, and the third line has a slope of $4/6=2/3$.

 We can easily check that these are not the same line.

 *)

fixes line1 line2 line3 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. line1 x y = (3 * y - 2 * x = 1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. line2 x y = (x + 2 * y = 2)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x y. line3 x y = (4 * x - 6 * y = 5)"
shows  "card {p. \<exists> x y. p = (x, y) \<and> ((line1 x y \<and> line2 x y) \<or> (line1 x y \<and> line3 x y) \<or> (line2 x y \<and> line3 x y))} = 2"
 proof-

a_0.informal problem: Find the number of points where at least two of the following three lines intersect: $3y - 2x = 1$, $x + 2y = 2$, and $4x - 6y = 5$. The final answer is 2.

and h1 : "\<forall>x y. x + 2 * y = 2"

shows  "card { (x, y). h0 x y \<or> h1 x y \<or> h2 x y } = 2"

fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. 3 * y - 2 * x = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. x + 2 * y = 2"
and h2 : "\<forall>x y. 4 * x - 6 * y = 5"

2. $x + 2y = 2$
3. $4x - 6y = 5$

and h2 : "4 * x - 6 * y = 5"

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. A x y = (3 * y - 2 * x = 1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. B x y = (x + 2 * y = 2)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x y. C x y = (4 * x - 6 * y = 5)"
and h3 : "card {p. \<exists> x y. A x y \<and> B x y \<and> p = (x, y) \<or> A x y \<and> C x y \<and> p = (x, y) \<or> B x y \<and> C x y \<and> p = (x, y)} = 2"
shows  "card {p. \<exists> x y. A x y \<and> B x y \<and> p = (x, y) \<or> A x y \<and> C x y \<and> p = (x, y) \<or> B x y \<and> C x y \<and> p = (x, y)} = 2"

(* ### Problem
 If the three lines $3y-2x=1$, $x+2y=2$ and $4x-6y=5$ are drawn in the plane, how many points will lie at the intersection of at least two of the three lines? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 In general, two lines intersect in exactly one point, unless they are parallel, in which case they are either the same line or have no intersection points. First, check to see if any of these lines are parallel.
 The first line $3y-2x=1$ has a slope of $2/3$,  the second line has a slope of $-1/2$, and the third line has a slope of $4/6=2/3$.
 So, the first and third lines are parallel.
 We can easily check that these are not the same line.
 Therefore, these two lines do not intersect anywhere, and the third line intersects each of them in exactly one point, for a total of $\boxed{2}$ intersection points.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. A x y = (3 * y - 2 * x = 1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. B x y = (x + 2 * y = 2)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x y. C x y = (4 * x - 6 * y = 5)"
and h3 : "card {p. \<exists> x y. A x y \<and> B x y \<and> p = (x, y) \<or> A x y \<and> C x y \<and> p = (x, y) \<or> B x y \<and> C x y \<and> p = (x, y)} = 2"
shows  "card {p. \<exists> x y. A x y \<and> B x y \<and> p = (x, y) \<or> A x y \<and> C x y \<and> p = (x, y) \<or> B x y \<and> C x y \<and> p = (x, y)} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

2. $x + 2y = 2$
3. $4x - 6y = 5$

theorem

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. l1 (x, y) = (3 * y - 2 * x = 1)"

shows  "card {p. (\<exists> x y. p = (x, y) \<and> (l1 (x, y) \<or> l2 (x, y) \<or> l3 (x, y)))} = 2"

shows  "card {p. (\<exists> x y. p = (x, y) \<and> (l1 (x, y) \<or> l2 (x, y) \<or> l3 (x, y)))} = 2"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
